values.alignmentText: Strong in enterprise, finance, and government IT (Brussels/Antwerp); multilingual teams common.
Urban NO2/PM in cores (ring roads); overall improving; stricter low-emission zones in cities.
Secular society with residual cultural Catholicism.
Consensus coalitions, independent courts, and EU oversight keep illiberal drift minimal despite occasional nationalist rhetoric.
SEPA/IBAN; contactless and instant payments; easy account opening with address ID.
North Sea coast with dunes/boardwalks; water cool; good walking/cycling; summer bathing short window.
Active café and club scenes in Brussels/Antwerp/Ghent.
Regional family allowances, subsidized crèches, and income-based fees create robust support, though spots fill quickly so waitlists should be tackled before arrival.
Playgrounds, libraries, leisure centres; compact cities ease access.
Citizens receive monthly allowances, generous parental leave, and subsidized crèche places capped around €30 per day.
Non-EU residents enrolled in social security can access subsidies after registration, but timing varies by region and status.
Cycling, football, hiking, festivals; cafés and board games popular.
Friendly locals; strong expat scene in Brussels; language communities active.
You must register within eight days, enroll in a mutualité, file annual Belgian taxes on worldwide income, and track integration courses if the region mandates them.
Brussels three-bedroom rents hover €1,600–1,900 and energy tariffs are steep, but Ghent or Leuven ease costs without sacrificing amenities.
Yes—Belgium permits dual nationality.
Advanced EU economy; strong services/logistics; regional differences.
Social market economy with robust safety nets.
Flemish schools score near the top of Europe and bilingual tracks abound, but French-speaking systems show more inequality, so choosing the right commune matters.
Available via Single Permit/EU Blue Card; larger firms and consultancies sponsor.
Diverse landscapes; strong environmental regulation; generally good environmental quality.
Mid-to-high effective rates depending on income/region; benefits offset for families.
Mild: ~10-18 C (50-64 F); increased rain/wind; pleasant shoulder season.
Parks, cycling culture, family-friendly amenities; museums and community facilities.
Spouse/partner/dependents eligible under reunification rules; documentation required.
Parental leave allowances, family allowances, subsidized childcare; varies by region/employer.
National frameworks broadly supportive; specifics vary by employer and regional delivery.
Residents with social security contributions access many supports; exact eligibility depends on status/region.
Practical chic; minimalist to casual; layered for weather.
Smart-casual with cycling/outdoor practicality; layers and quality footwear.
Modern European fashion; weather-aware layering; practical chic.
Growing indie and serious games; fewer AAA; Brussels/Flanders hubs.

As noted in Game Dev Work Prospects, Growing indie and serious games; fewer AAA; Brussels/Flanders hubs. Hiring velocity at established studios in Belgium is moderate, with teams needing a few months to land the right hire.

Compensation clusters around global medians, requiring negotiation to balance cost of living. When opportunities surface in Belgium, established studios benchmark offers against peers across the ecosystem.
Established studios in Belgium rely on English for cross-border collaboration, while local-language fluency remains important for community, compliance, and platform partnerships.
Remote expectations at established studios in Belgium are mixed—teams juggle on-site collaboration with hybrid arrangements when possible.
Legal recognition; social acceptance rising in cities.
Strong legal protections and EU alignment.
Increasingly egalitarian; high female workforce participation; policy supports.
Commune registration, health insurance, bank/lease proofs; driver licence exchange; language admin in Dutch/French.
Increasing heatwaves and rainfall extremes; localized river/coastal flood risk; mitigation ongoing.
Compulsory mutualité insurance reimburses 60–75% of costs and pediatric specialists are easy to access, with modest co-pays.
Once registered, visa holders join the same mutualité system; newcomers often carry private insurance for the first months until residence paperwork clears.
Domestic tuition at public universities; grants/loans; strong networks in Leuven/Brussels/Ghent/Liege.
International tuition for most temporary visas; scholarships limited; improves with long-term residence/EU status.
Moderate prices outside Brussels; Brussels rents higher; energy standards tightening.
PAYE for employees; annual returns; progressive tax with social contributions; complex but well-documented.
Free public K-12; zoning applies; quality varies by network/region; strong language education.
Resident children generally enroll in public schools; language support available; documentation required.
English works well in Brussels’ EU bubble, but schools and paperwork run in Dutch or French, so the family should plan language study for long-term integration.
Legal equality; strong acceptance in cities; pride events.
Limited mainstream; present in academic/activist circles.
Smart-casual; focus on practicality and cycling/outdoor wear.
Strong meetup culture, especially in Brussels tech/NGO spheres.
Statutory minimum wage with sectoral agreements; uprated periodically.
High modernity: broadband/5G, cycling networks, digital gov; occasional regional gaps.
Ardennes forests/hills, Flemish countryside, coastal dunes; charming historic towns.
Low seismic risk; main hazards are floods, windstorms, and heatwaves.
Dense trail/canal networks; short travel to parks/forests/coast from major cities.
Vibrant in Brussels/Antwerp/Ghent; festivals year-round; smaller towns quieter.
Active in Brussels/Antwerp/Ghent; cafes/bars/clubs; smaller towns quieter; generally safe.
Local meetups/jams in Brussels/Antwerp/Ghent; access to nearby EU events.
Larian (BE-origin), Happy Volcano; proximity to EU hubs.
Regional funds (VAF/Gamefonds, screen.brussels), EU programs; good publisher access across EU.

Startup founders report that Regional funds (VAF/Gamefonds, screen.brussels), EU programs; good publisher access across EU. Hiring velocity at early-stage studios in Belgium wraps searches within a month or two as pipelines stay active.
Compensation remains competitive with other major hubs, mixing solid base pay and performance bonuses. Early teams in Belgium balance cash and equity to stay competitive while managing runway.
Founding teams in Belgium lean on English for investor and platform communication, while local-language fluency helps with hiring, compliance, and community outreach.
Remote expectations among startups in Belgium are flexible for senior roles, with hybrid schedules common.
Moderate; Brussels faster, regional cities/towns calmer.
Balanced; extracurriculars common; emphasis on languages/sports.
Typically 5 years of legal residence plus integration and language proof.
Low by international standards; strong oversight.
Federal parliamentary monarchy with regional governments; complex but stable.
Social acceptance limited; discretion advisable outside progressive circles.
Creches (0-3) subsidized; maternelle widely available from ~2.5; capacity varies by commune.
Independent/international schools in Brussels/Antwerp; higher fees; selective admissions.
High on social policies; pragmatic politics; coalition culture.
Pluralistic media; state and private broadcasters; partisan framing exists.
Moderate; counterbalanced by public and independent outlets.
STIB/De Lijn/SNCB networks weave trams, buses, and trains across cities with real-time apps and easy bike connections, keeping car-free living practical.
Limited direct influence; secular governance predominant.
EU institutions normalized remote collaboration, coworking hubs span Brussels and Ghent, and time zones align well with both US East Coast evenings and EU partners.
A-card residence permits; renewals leading to long-term residence (EU LTR).
Pension via social insurance; adequacy depends on contributions/housing; private pillars helpful.
Eligibility/portability tied to contributions/status; bilateral treaties may help.
Smaller market; present in startups/scale-ups; fewer roles than Java/.NET.
Generally safe; petty theft in tourist cores; low violent crime.
Free public schools (secular and faith streams); Dutch/French systems; some immersion/bilingual programs.
~7-19 C (45-66 F); short late-summer comfort; wetsuits common for longer season.
Temperate maritime: cool summers, mild winters, frequent rain/overcast; regional differences Flanders/Wallonia/Ardennes.
Liberal urban norms; comprehensive sex ed; media openness.
Robust social security, healthcare, and family benefits systems.
Typical daytime ~9-16 C (48-61 F); frequent showers; more sun toward late spring.
Stable but frequent coalition negotiations; daily life largely unaffected.
Social market economy; centrist coalitions.
Advanced mixed capitalist economy.
Typical ~17-24 C (63-75 F); episodic heatwaves >30 C; humidity moderate; cooler near coast.
Processing usually months; fees moderate; commune-level variation.
Moderate; coalition dynamics can lower trust during stalemates.
Low systemic corruption; occasional procurement/local issues.
Lower than NL/DE but competitive locally; benefits often strong; costs moderate in secondary cities.
Markets, parks, cycling, festivals; retail hours vary Sundays; family/cafe culture.
Schools often ~08:30-15:30; offices ~08:30-17:30; after-school care varies by commune; biking/transit common.
Legal minimum ~20 days for full-time plus public holidays.
Often 25-30+ including seniority/sectoral additions.
Positive/pragmatic engagement with NL/FR/DE/LU/UK.
Pragmatic, multilingual, community-focused, European.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Seen as cooperative EU partner; Brussels as administrative hub.
Single Permit and EU Blue Card routes hinge on employer sponsorship and salary thresholds; self-employed visas demand business plans reviewed by regional authorities.
Brussels’ expat bubble is warm to US families, while Flemish communes expect quick Dutch acquisition before you feel fully included.
Multilingual culture, EU hub (Brussels), great cycling, central EU location for travel.
Cool: ~1-7 C (34-45 F); damp chill; frost/ice possible; snow mainly Ardennes.
Typically around 38 hours; flex/time-credit schemes exist.
A 38-hour cap, time-credit schemes, and five-plus weeks of leave help Sarah maintain calmer rhythms, though bilingual offices can stretch meetings across time zones.
Strong protections, collective bargaining, workplace safety; unions influential.
Meaningful swings appear a few times per season; we budget extra time and gear to handle sudden cold snaps or storm systems.
Deep winter gloom lasts several weeks, so we plan strict routines, supplements, and possible getaways to maintain morale.
Roughly half the year is wonderful, half demands planning around heat, cold, or rain to enjoy time outside.
Basic needs are met but savings and extracurriculars are hard to sustain without extra support or side work.
Housing and childcare strain the budget, limiting savings and discretionary spending most months.
Affluent households encounter noticeable friction—specialists, tutors, or clubs are scarce or highly gated.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: Most 2k sq ft options feel overpriced or stuck in fringe neighborhoods with weaker schools.
We can find a few reputable co-living or cooperative projects though demand may require patience.
Locals are polite and willing to connect when we show initiative, though relationships build gradually.
Sentiment splits; friendly communities exist but national discourse can turn skeptical.
Reception depends on class and language; we must adapt quickly to avoid perceptions of aloofness.
Friendly exchanges happen when we initiate; staff and strangers respond positively.
Relationships deepen steadily with consistent effort; vulnerability is appreciated though not automatic.
Expect to navigate varied norms—crowded spaces or warm cultures may lean into closer contact.
We balance honesty with cultural nuance to avoid unintentionally offending.
We feel a gentle push to stay polished in professional or social spaces.
We notice subtle comparisons; maintaining confidence requires occasional boundary setting.
Certain districts expect polished outfits, though flexibility exists in family spaces.
Boundaries are understood yet alcohol-fueled scenes need watchfulness.
Mostly flexible though some circles still expect traditional roles on first approach.
We can find community yet must manage privacy carefully to avoid backlash. non-monogamy acceptance.
Attitudes split; open discussion is fine in urban enclaves yet frowned upon elsewhere.
Social services lack frameworks, so we navigate paperwork carefully and expect occasional bias.
We occasionally experience closer contact than preferred but can steer interactions politely.
Laws are moderate; we occasionally encounter firearms but rarely feel threatened.
Possession laws are moderate though some substances still carry steep fines.
Most enforcement is targeted though occasional crackdowns create unease.
Recent history shows sporadic mass violence, so we stay vigilant at large gatherings.
Conditions are generally decent though some facilities lag in services or transparency.
Sidewalks cover key areas but drivers often rush, so we stay alert with children.
Health-conscious communities exist alongside more laid-back groups; resources are readily available.
Processed foods are common but balanced by strong fresh markets.
Strong selection overall though certain cuisines require a bit of travel.
Mental health burdens exist but are met with accessible services and open dialogue.
We monitor diet and activity because obesity is moderately common.
Rates align with global norms; screening and early detection programs are reliable.
Market depends on a few key industries, so we maintain contingency plans.
